entry.title: Chrome 133 Goodies
entry.summary: Did you see the release notes for Chrome 133? It's currently in beta, but the Chrome team has been publishing a slew of new articles with pretty incredible demos that are tough to ignore. I figured I'd round those up in one place. Chrome 133 Goodies originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Keeping the page interactive while a View Transition is running
entry.summary: When using View Transitions youâ€™ll notice the page becomes unresponsive to clicks while a View Transition is running. [â€¦] This happens because of theÂ ::view-transitionÂ pseudo element â€“ the one that contains all animated snapshots â€“ gets overlayed on top â€¦ Keeping the page interactive while a View Transition is running originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: The Mistakes of CSS
entry.summary: All of the things that the CSS Working Group would change if they had a time-traveling Delorean to go back and do things over. The Mistakes of CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: What on Earth is theÂ `types`Â Descriptor in View Transitions?
entry.summary: The @view-transition at-rule has two descriptions. One is the commonly used navigation descriptor. The second is types, the lesser-known of the two, and one that probably envies how much attentionÂ navigationÂ gets. But read on to learn why we need types and how it opens up new possibilities for custom view transitions when navigating between pages. What on Earth is theÂ `types`Â Descriptor in View Transitions? originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Revisiting CSS Multi-Column Layout
entry.summary: After 20 years since Andy Clarke first published his book about Multi-Column Layout in CSS, he's back to encourage a fresh look at CSS columns for enhanced readability and design flexibility. Revisiting CSS Multi-Column Layout originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Positioning Text Around Elements With CSS Offset
entry.summary: When it comes to positioning elements on a page, including text, there are many ways to go about it in CSS â€” the literal position property with corresponding inset-* properties, translate, margin, anchor() (limited browser support at the moment), and so forth. The offset property is another one that belongs in that list. Positioning Text Around Elements With CSS Offset originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
